awd_abstract_narration:
In this planning grant, the WATT project research team will explore the potential for autonomy technologies to improve the efficiency, productivity, safety, and security of the organic waste processing industry. Methane released from organic waste (e.g., food scraps) accounts for a significant percentage of greenhouse gases released into the atmosphere that contribute to the warming of the planet, and by extension, climate change. The current methods of sorting and processing organic waste are inefficient, hazardous, and undertaken primarily by low-wage temporary workers who lack job security, living wages and benefits. The research undertaken by the WATT project research team will lay the foundation for future social and technological innovations within the organic waste processing industry that will increase operational efficiency, create job stability, skills training, and upward mobility for workers, create opportunities for human-machine teaming, and ultimately reduce the impact of this industry on climate change while uplifting workers.

The WATT research team, through a transdisciplinary approach consisting of real-time, on-site observations, focus groups, surveys, and interviews with waste industry stakeholders (line workers, business owners, safety inspectors/enforcers), will identify socio-technological innovations that will address the challenges with separation, conversion to energy, legal frameworks, adaptation of best practices, and climate change analyses in the context of organic waste processing. The research team consists of faculty, graduate and undergraduate students, and subject matter experts representing a diverse cross-section of academic disciplines (e.g., waste management, manufacturing and mechanical engineering, computer science, business, law, anthropology, and art and design), an integral and critical piece of the project’s approach, that will reveal holistic, transdisciplinary approaches for improving an industry critical to the responsible functioning of a 21st century society.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The principal outcome of the Planning Proposal in Phase I is to generate the  workplan for Phase II, which is summarized below:

FW-HTF-RL Workers and Technology Together (WATT) offers a unique opportunity toresearch technology-based solutions that improve labor conditions and increase materialsrecovery. WATT will address the critical need for breakthrough technologies that enable dualaugmented reality-based and workplace-based learning and rapid upskilling of the waste
characterization workforce on complex, physically and cognitively demanding, and hard-to-automate tasks. Based on our phase 1 results ( NSF Award ID 2129137), we will develop a
research test bed at several Materials Recovery Facilities (MRFs) and use an innovative AI-basedsensor-fusion and remote robotic teleoperation system, AVATAR (AI-powered Vision andAugmented reality for Teleoperation Assisted Recycling), for automated waste characterization.The convergence research team will create new technological pathways to enable intelligentworker-AVATAR teaming and advance the fundamental understanding of its impacts on laboreconomy and worker learning and innovation. This project aims to create new perspectives,methods, and discoveries to unleash the full potential of America’s waste management workforceand strengthen national prosperity and economic competitiveness in waste characterization.WATT’s three research questions for Phase II are:1. Can we produce actionable data that assists MRF operators in making informed decisionsto optimize material recovery and identify opportunities for improving working conditionswithin the MRF environment?2. Can we leverage this data to develop MRF robotic systems that can effectively augmentthe physical processes involved in material recovery and contribute to measurableimprovements in working conditions and material recovery?3. Can we disseminate this solution across the wider industry to create a meaningful andsustainable impact on MRF workplace conditions and material recovery worldwide?The team has identified three project goals with associated measurable outcomes:● Goal 1: To increase the recovery of recyclable materials● Goal 2: To improve the work environment for workers in materials recovery facilities● Goal 3: To improve workers’ trust and safety with automation technologiesThe research activities undertaken as part of the FW-HTF-RL WATT project will measurablyimprove two distinct but interrelated areas: operational improvements across an industry thathas a direct impact on the health of the planet and the working conditions (health/safety,wages/benefits, job security, upward mobility, skill attainment) for line workers in wasteprocessing facilities. The research conducted during Phase I provided WATT with the knowledgeand know-how to research AVATAR as a realistic, cost-effective, and feasible innovation that canalign the U.S. with other industrialized nations’ methods for processing waste. With corporatechange and upskilling, workers will not fear being displaced by “so-so” technologies. Instead,AVATAR will create a context for symbiotic working relationships between humans andtechnology, thereby improving the economic and health and safety outcomes for workers.Phase II implementation will provide the know-how for our long-term mission: Todischarge WATT’s best practices and commercialize AVATAR for MRFsinternationally, making an indelible impact worldwide on environmental justice andsocial change.
